awd_titl_txt: RUI: Methodological and theoretical advances in the perception of multiracial individuals
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past five decades, the number of individuals in the U.S. identifying as multiracial has increased exponentially. In 2000, the U.S. Census began allowing individuals to indicate more than one race. From 2000 to 2010 alone, such responses increased by 32%, to 9 million. Yet, research suggests that the American multiracial population has grown much faster than the public's ability to perceive individuals as multiracial. For example, a person identifying as both African American and Caucasian will tend to be seen by others as African American only. One explanation is that people have not yet added a concept of multiracialism to the monoracial categories that are woven into the American social fabric. This disconnect between the real and assumed racial identity of a large and rapidly growing segment of the American population carries adverse impacts that have been well-documented by researchers. This project investigates how human minds process and racially categorize the faces of multiracial individuals. It also examines how experiences shape the capacity to view people as multiracial. A better understanding of the cognitive and social influences on the perception of multiracial individuals can be used to help reduce stereotyping, contribute to a more positive identity formation, and foster more harmonious interpersonal relationships.

This project first seeks to establish a set of "best practices" for experimentation using multiracial faces. One set of experiments examines differences in how people judge real versus computer-generated multiracial faces. These studies also consider how the categorization of multiracial faces is affected by the range of presented race options. Statistical modeling techniques are used to determine the precise features of a face that lead others to perceive it as multiracial and to create a set of multiracial faces that can be used by other researchers. The second aim of the project is to determine whether multiracial faces constitute a unique category in the minds of perceivers, or if they are perceptually similar to members of a dominant monoracial category. The third aim is to test whether certain personal attributes or life experiences are associated with a higher likelihood of perceiving multiracialism in others. As a Hispanic-Serving and an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution, California State University, Northridge offers an excellent opportunity to integrate this research project in the training of undergraduate and Master's students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The world population is experiencing massive growth in the proportion of individuals identifying as multiracial, a demographic trend that challenges traditional “either-or” conceptions of race and thus carries the potential to reshape how we understand and react to race as a society. At the same time, research on face categorization has demonstrated that people spontaneously perceive nearly all faces as belonging to monoracial or monoethnic groups, even faces of individuals who self-identify as multiracial. This means that multiracial individuals are often misclassified or simply treated ambiguously by others, which carries important consequences for their sense of belonging and well-being. Our project was designed to help answer the following questions: first, in a society that is rapidly becoming more multiracial, are most people only able to perceive others as being of a single race? Do they have the capacity to see others as multiracial, but avoid doing so for other reasons? What are the mental processes that take place as someone attempts to categorize a racially ambiguous face? And what is the best way for scientists who study the perception of multiracial people to define multiracialism?

Our first major outcome was the expansion of the Chicago Face Database, a large set of high-quality face images that are free and available to the public and the research community, to include the faces of self-identified multiracial individuals. While most research on multiracial face perception has used either artificial multiracial faces (computer-generated or “morphed” faces) or small numbers of natural multiracial faces, the multiracial expansion of the CFD allows for studies that include large numbers of natural faces. This effort was designed to overcome practical limitations on the variety and representativeness of the faces that can be used in research.

With a large number of real multiracial faces now available, we were able to test an important question for research on multiracial face perception: do people’s perceptions of multiracial faces depend on whether those faces are morphs (created by mathematically averaging two monoracial faces) versus images of real multiracial faces? In a series of experiments, we learned that people are more likely to label a face “multiracial” when it is an artificial multiracial morph than when it is a real multiracial face. This finding demonstrates that what kind of multiracial face one uses in research matters. If a researcher’s goal is to use the type of face that more closely matches multiracial faces seen in everyday life, they should use pictures of real faces, but if their goal is to present a face that people will more likely judge to be multiracial, morphs may be advisable. We also found that multiracial faces with hair showing are more likely to be categorized as multiracial than those presented without hair showing, suggesting that hair is an important cue to people when they categorize racially ambiguous faces.

In another set of experiments, we tested the possibility that people usually label multiracial faces monoracial because they have difficulty telling these two types of faces apart. We asked people to rate the similarities of many pairs of faces and used a statistical technique to create a perceptual “map” that showed whether multiracial faces look the same as monoracial faces to people or whether they look distinct. Our results showed that people do perceive differences between the multiracial and monoracial faces in our experiments: multiracial faces occupy their own unique area of the perceptual map, separate from monoracial faces. This finding, which we have repeated in several experiments using a variety of different faces, indicates that people are perceptually capable of distinguishing multiracial from monoracial faces, but that something in their decision-making process prevents them from exercising this ability when it comes to classifying their race.

Understanding what influences this decision process and determining the extent to which it can be adjusted to reflect an increasingly multiracial population are important topics for research. In one such line of experiments, we investigated the role of social and political values in the perception of Vice President Kamala Harris, the first multiracial woman on a major party ticket in United States history. Contrary to our expectation based on prior research, we found no evidence that one’s political orientation corresponded to perceptions of Harris’s face; perceptual maps of both liberals and conservatives evidenced that she was highly distinct from both Black and Indian faces that reflect her multiracial heritage. Interestingly, conservative participants were much more likely than liberal participants to classify her as White, a potential example of motivated reasoning impacting race categorization decisions.

In the process of carrying out these and other experiments, we had the opportunity to train, financially support, and offer professional development to many undergraduate and Master’s students as they gained experience in all facets of scientific research and worked towards applying to graduate programs in psychology.
